choices.text: Full visual acuity develops by 6 years of age
The macula is fully formed at birth
The cornea reaches adult diameter by the age of 2
The lens continues to grow throughout life

questions.text: Which of the following statements about eye development is incorrect?
questions.solution: Ans. B) The macula is fully formed at birth

choices.text: Mozart ear – Fusion of helix and antihelix

questions.text: All of the following are correctly matched congenital pinna anomalies, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Wildermuth ear – Large pinna

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman has difficulty seeing in bright light and is diagnosed with a cataract. Which cataract type is not typically associated with this symptom?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Cuneiform cataract

questions.text: Which of the following audiogram patterns suggests retrocochlear pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) d

 

Audiogram curve "d" demonstrates the classic "roll over phenomenon," where speech discrimination worsens as sound intensity increases, a hallmark of retrocochlear pathology (such as vestibular schwannoma). In this pattern, discrimination scores peak at a lower intensity and then decrease with further amplification, indicating neural rather than sensory loss. Thus, the correct answer is d.

 

This curve is most consistent with retrocochlear lesions, distinct from other curves that indicate normal hearing or sensorineural loss without rollover.

 

Here,

 

  • Curve a: Normal / conductive pattern (rapid rise, excellent discrimination).
  • Curve b: Conductive loss – shifted to right, but still high discrimination at adequate intensity.
  • Curve c: Poor cochlear function – plateaus at a lower maximum discrimination.
  • Curve d: Retrocochlear pathology – rollover pattern (discrimination worsens with higher amplification).

 

Labelled image is shown below:

questions.text: The binocular vision grade shown in the image corresponds to:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Grade III

choices.text: The middle layer of the tympanic membrane is derived from mesoderm and contains radial, circular, and parabolic fibers
The outer epithelial layer is continuous with the skin of the external auditory canal and is derived from ectoderm
The inner mucosal layer is derived from ectoderm and is continuous with the middle ear mucosa
The region called Shrapnell’s membrane does not transmit sound

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the tympanic membrane are correct, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The inner mucosal layer is derived from ectoderm and is continuous with the middle ear mucosa

 

  1. Outer epithelial layer:
    • Derived from ectoderm.
    • Continuous with the skin of the external auditory canal.
  2. Middle fibrous layer
    • Derived from mesoderm.:
    • Contains radial, circular, and parabolic fibers that provide strength and elasticity.
    • Absent in the pars flaccida (Shrapnell’s membrane).
  3. Inner mucosal layer:
    • Derived from endoderm.
    • Continuous with the mucosa of the middle ear cavity.

 

The incorrect statement in the question is option C, because it wrongly says the inner mucosal layer is from ectoderm. It is actually from endoderm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle layer derived from mesoderm and contains radial, circular, and parabolic fibers: Correct. Provides structural support to the tympanic membrane.

 

Option B. Outer epithelial layer continuous with skin of external auditory canal and derived from ectoderm: Correct. The outermost layer is ectodermal in origin.

 

Option D. Shrapnell’s membrane (pars flaccida) does not transmit sound: Correct. Pars flaccida lacks the fibrous middle layer, hence does not contribute to sound conduction.

choices.text: The lateral one-third is made of auricular yellow elastic cartilage
The bony part of the canal is lined with thick skin containing ceruminous glands
The medial two-thirds is formed by the temporal bone
Fissures of Santorini are seen in the cartilaginous part

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the external auditory canal are correct, except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) The bony part of the canal is lined with thick skin containing ceruminous glands

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distress syndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks from now would you schedule the screening?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 2 weeks

choices.text: Central perforation in the anteroinferior quadrant
Granulations and red fleshy polyps are common

questions.text: All of the following are features of attico-antral type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Central perforation in the anteroinferior quadrant

 

Because central perforation in the anteroinferior quadrant is characteristic of the tubo-tympanic (safe) type of CSOM, not attico-antral.

 

Attico-antral CSOM is the unsafe type, usually involving the attic or posterior-superior part of the tympanic membrane.


It is characterized by marginal/attic perforation, cholesteatoma, granulations, and foul-smelling discharge.


The disease causes bone erosion with risk of serious extracranial and intracranial complications.


Surgery (mastoidectomy) is the definitive treatment to achieve a safe, dry ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Also called the unsafe type: True. Attico-antral disease is considered unsafe because of risk of serious complications (mastoiditis, facial palsy, intracranial spread).

 

Option B. Cholesteatoma is present: True. Cholesteatoma (keratinizing squamous epithelium in middle ear) is a hallmark of attico-antral CSOM, leading to bone erosion.

 

Option D. Granulations and red fleshy polyps are common: True. Granulation tissue and aural polyps often accompany the chronic inflammatory process in unsafe type CSOM.

choices.text: Primary acquired cholesteatoma is due to defect in pars flaccida
Congenital cholesteatoma arises from epithelial cell rests
Secondary acquired cholesteatoma involves pars tensa
Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma originates from retraction pockets

questions.text: All of the following regarding cholesteatoma are correct, except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Tertiary acquired is due to implantation, not retraction pockets

questions.text: All of the following contribute to the formation of the nasal septum, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Inferior nasal concha

questions.text: In acute suppurative otitis media, during which phase is the ear pain at its peak intensity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage of suppuration

 

In acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM), the disease progresses through well-defined stages.

 

  • During the stage of suppuration, pus collects in the middle ear cavity, leading to marked rise in middle ear pressure.
  • This pressure stretches the tympanic membrane to its maximum, making it intensely congested and bulging.
  • At this stage, the patient experiences severe, throbbing ear pain at its peak intensity.

 

 

Stages of ASOM are:

 

1. Stage of Tubal Occlusion

 

  • Eustachian tube blockage
  • Negative middle ear pressure
  • Retraction of tympanic membrane

 

2. Stage of Pre-suppuration (Hyperemia / Congestion Stage)

 

  • Middle ear mucosa congested and edematous
  • Tympanic membrane congested, opaque
  • Mild to moderate ear pain begins

 

3. Stage of Suppuration

 

  • Pus formation in middle ear
  • Tympanic membrane bulges, highly congested
  • Severe, throbbing ear pain at its peak
  • Conductive hearing loss

 

4. Stage of Resolution (Perforation Stage)

 

  • Tympanic membrane perforates
  • Purulent discharge appears, pain suddenly relieved
  • Hearing loss persists but less pain

questions.text: In which of the following situations is retrobulbar block considered safe?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Enucleation

questions.text: What position will the vocal cords most likely be in after complete bilateral paralysis following total thyroidectomy?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Intermediate

choices.text: Macular dystrophy stains with Alcian blue
Schnyder's dystrophy shows mucopolysaccharides with Congo red
Granular dystrophy is stained by Masson trichome

questions.text: All are true about corneal dystrophies and stains used except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Schnyder's dystrophy shows phospholipids and stains with Oil red

choices.text: Most commonly due to inferior rectus stimulation

questions.text: All are true about the oculocardiac reflex except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Most commonly due to inferior rectus stimulation

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents for tympanoplasty. During the surgery, the surgeon finds that both the malleus and incus are absent. According to Wullstein's classification, which type of tympanoplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

According to Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty, the types are categorized based on the extent of ossicular chain involvement and the placement of the tympanic membrane graft:

 

  • Type I: The tympanic membrane graft is placed on an intact and functioning ossicular chain.
  • Type II: The tympanic membrane graft is placed on the incus, with the malleus absent or eroded.
  • Type III: The tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes head when both the malleus and incus are absent. This reconstructs the sound conduction mechanism to use the stapes as the connection to the inner ear.
  • Type IV: The tympanic membrane graft is placed over the round window to protect it when the stapes is eroded or absent.

 

In this case, with both the malleus and incus absent, the graft is directly placed on the stapes, fitting the criteria for Type III tympanoplasty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: This involves placement of the tympanic membrane graft on an intact and functioning ossicular chain, which is not applicable here as both the malleus and incus are absent.

 

Option B. Type II: This involves graft placement on the incus with the malleus absent or eroded. However, in this case, the incus is also absent, so Type II tympanoplasty does not apply.

 

Option D. Type IV: This involves covering the round window with a tympanic membrane graft when the stapes is eroded or absent, which is not the scenario here as the stapes is present and intact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Type III tympanoplasty, the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes head when both the malleus and incus are absent, as per Wullstein’s classification.

choices.text: 5 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
3 or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva
5 or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva
3 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva

questions.text: According to the grading of trachoma, what defines the follicular stage?
questions.solution: Ans. A) 5 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva

questions.text: Austin’s classification of ossicular chain defects is based on which components?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malleus handle and stapes suprastructure

 

  • Austin's classification of ossicular chain defects focuses on:
  • Malleus handle (the part of the malleus that connects to the tympanic membrane) and the stapes suprastructure (the upper part of the stapes that connects to the oval window).

 

The classification helps to identify the nature of the defect and determine the surgical treatment approach

questions.text: A student with myopia wishes to undergo surgery. Which option is not suitable for correcting her refractive error?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Conductive keratoplasty

questions.text: A patient complains of "fluctuating refractory error”. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Diabetic cataract

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to overwhelming anxiety and stress. The patient is an accountant and has been under increasing job-related pressure for the past 6 weeks due to an upcoming tax deadline. She says, "The worst part is that I get really nervous all of a sudden and then feel shaky, dizzy, and nauseated and start to sweat. It happened while I spoke to my boss a few weeks ago, and I had to excuse myself." The patient is especially worried about having an episode during a work meeting, although she notes that her symptoms have also occurred while she was relaxing at home. She says, "I've stopped going out with my friends because I never know when I'm going to feel this way." Blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 18/min. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Panic disorder

 

This patient describes recurrent, unexpected panic attacks characterized by sudden onset of intense anxiety, autonomic arousal (sweating, palpitations, dizziness, nausea, trembling), and fear. Importantly, the attacks are not limited to specific situations (they occur both at work and while relaxing at home). She has also developed avoidance behavior (stopped going out with friends) due to fear of future attacks. These features fulfill criteria for panic disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress disorder: This occurs within 3 days to 4 weeks of a traumatic event, with intrusive memories, dissociation, avoidance, and hyperarousal. There is no trauma described here, so this is not correct.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder with anxious mood: This is emotional/behavioural symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor within 3 months, disproportionate to the stressor. In this case, although the patient has work stress, her attacks also occur in non-stressful situations and show classic panic features, making adjustment disorder unlikely.

 

Option C. Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by excessive, chronic worry about multiple aspects of life for ≥6 months, with symptoms such as restlessness, fatigue, muscle tension, and sleep disturbance. This patient instead has episodic, sudden panic attacks rather than persistent worry, which points to panic disorder.

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is evaluated for fatigue. For the last year, he has been avoiding any significant outdoor activities with his peers due to poor energy and shortness of breath. Physical examination shows a holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower sternal border. Echocardiography reveals apical displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets. Moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation is also present. If this patient's diagnosis is due to a side effect of a drug taken during pregnancy, his biological mother most likely had which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Bipolar disorder

questions.text: What is the primary material used in manufacturing soft contact lenses?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Hydroxyethyl methyl acrylate

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after her husband found her confused. The patient was unable to answer questions about why she did not go to work that day and could not remember the day of the week. She has a history of bipolar disorder and has taken the same dose of lithium for the past 10 years. Over the past week, the patient started taking several daily doses of a new medication following a dental extraction. Yesterday, she felt nauseated and vomited twice, and earlier today, she started having diarrhea. Coarse tremors are noted in the upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in the bilateral extremities. A drug interaction involving which of the following medications is most likely causing this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ibuprofen

 

This patient with long-term lithium use for bipolar disorder has developed confusion, coarse tremor, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which are classic signs of lithium toxicity. Her symptoms began after starting a new medication following dental extraction. Among the options, NSAIDs such as ibuprofen decrease renal clearance of lithium by reducing prostaglandin synthesis → decreased renal blood flow → increased reabsorption of lithium in the proximal tubule → elevated serum lithium levels and toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetaminophen: Safe to use with lithium. It does not affect renal clearance or lithium levels.

 

Option C. Ondansetron: Used as an antiemetic for nausea and vomiting. It has no significant interaction with lithium metabolism or excretion.

 

Option D. Prednisone: Corticosteroids can cause fluid and electrolyte disturbances but are not known for causing significant drug interaction leading to lithium toxicity.

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and fluctuating course of symptoms. The level of consciousness and attention varies throughout the day, often worsening at night (sundowning). It is an indicator of underlying organic dysfunction and differentiates delirium from chronic conditions like dementia or psychosis. The fluctuating nature of symptoms is a hallmark of delirium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: Delirium develops acutely over hours to days, whereas a gradual course is more typical of dementia.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: Consciousness is impaired in delirium with fluctuating alertness, unlike in dementia or psychiatric illnesses where it is preserved.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: Visual hallucinations are more common in delirium, while auditory hallucinations are characteristic of psychiatric disorders like schizophrenia.

 

Summary Table: Delirium vs Dementia:

questions.text: A carpenter develops bilateral eye irritation and vision loss after trauma to the right eye. Fundus exam reveals Dalen-Fuchs nodules. Which type of hypersensitivity is involved?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Type 4

choices.text: Halos remain intact but brightness is reduced
Halos are broken and revolve as the slit moves
No halos are visible through the stenopaic slit

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the Fincham’s test result in a patient with lenticular halo?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Halos are broken and revolve as the slit moves

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with leukocoria and calcified intraocular masses is found to have tumors 4–10 DD in size behind the equator. According to Reese-Ellsworth classification, to which group does this case belong?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Group 2

questions.text: The FDA approved medication to aid in smoking cessation include all except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Buspirone

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after his sister found him unresponsive. Several days ago, he was discharged from an inpatient addiction centre, where he was treated for multiple substance use disorders and long-standing bipolar disorder. The patient's sister states that he has been depressed and has not taken any of his prescribed medications since discharge. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 10/min. The patient is obtunded and unresponsive to verbal commands. Physical examination shows 2-mm pupils. The patient is ventilated by bag valve mask, and supplemental oxygen and intravenous fluids are initiated. Which of the following should be administered next?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Naloxone

choices.text: NVD of any disc area with VH is high-risk
Vitreous hemorrhage with NVE is a high-risk feature
Clinically significant macular edema includes thickening within 500 µm of fovea
Tractional retinal detachment is a sign of NPDR

questions.text: All are true about diabetic retinopathy features except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Tractional retinal detachment is a sign of NPDR

questions.text: MK medium used for corneal preservation is effective for:
questions.solution: Ans. D) 48 to 72 hours

questions.text: 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to sudden-onset double vision that started immediately after she woke up. The patient notices that her vision worsens when looking to the right. She has no headache, weakness, or numbness. Neurologic examination, including visual acuity, is normal with the exception of the ocular findings shown in the image below. A lesion involving which of the following structures is most likely causing the observed ocular findings in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Medial longitudinal fasciculus

questions.text: A 25-year-old graduate student with a history of recurrent ear infections as a child feels anxious and sweats when she is in the examination room with her primary care physician. She recently got a roommate, a nursing student, who leaves her stethoscope on the coffee table after returning from class. The patient sweats and feels her heart start to race whenever she sees the stethoscope. This patient's response to her roommate's stethoscope is an example of which of the following phenomena?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classical conditioning

 

In this case, the patient experiences sweating and anxiety when she sees a stethoscope. The stethoscope, which was once a neutral stimulus, has become a conditioned stimulus after repeated pairing with stressful doctor visits that caused anxiety. This is a classic example of classical conditioning where a neutral object acquires the ability to trigger a learned emotional or physical response through association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Negative punishment: Negative punishment means removing a pleasant stimulus after a behavior to decrease the chance of that behavior happening again. For example, if a child misbehaves and their parents take away their toy, this is negative punishment. In the patient’s case, no positive stimulus is being taken away, so this does not fit.

 

Option C. Negative reinforcement: Negative reinforcement occurs when removal of an unpleasant stimulus makes a behavior more likely to occur in the future. For example, wearing earplugs to avoid loud noise encourages the behavior of wearing earplugs again. Here, the patient is not removing an unpleasant stimulus after any behavior, so it is not negative reinforcement.

 

Option D. Operant conditioning: Operant conditioning involves learning through consequences of behavior such as reinforcement or punishment. For example, giving a dog a treat for sitting increases the chance the dog will sit again. The patient’s anxiety is not due to consequences of her own actions but rather to an automatic association with a stimulus, so operant conditioning is not correct.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the loss of recent memories more severe than remote memories?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde amnesia

 

In retrograde amnesia, there is loss of memory for events that occurred before the onset of the amnesia. The pattern is typically temporally graded, meaning that recent memories are lost more severely than older memories. This happens because older memories are more firmly consolidated in long-term storage, while recent ones are still vulnerable to disruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterograde amnesia: This refers to the inability to form new memories after the onset of the condition. Patients can remember past events but struggle to create and store new information. It does not primarily affect past memories, so it is not the correct choice here.

 

Option C. Global amnesia: This condition involves both anterograde and retrograde amnesia, where patients cannot form new memories and also lose some past memories. However, the defining feature in the question is recent memories being more severely affected than remote, which specifically fits retrograde amnesia.

 

Option D. Senile dementia: In dementia, memory loss is progressive and involves both recent and remote memories, but recent memories are usually affected first due to impaired short-term recall. However, the mechanism is different, and the key feature of temporally graded loss as described in the question best matches retrograde amnesia.

choices.text: Can be seen in occipital lobe neoplasms

questions.text: All are true about Foster–Kennedy syndrome except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Can be seen in occipital lobe neoplasms

questions.text: Subcortical dementia can occur in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alzheimer's disease

 

Alzheimer’s disease is a cortical type of dementia characterized by predominant involvement of the cerebral cortex. The main deficits are in memory, language, and higher cognitive functions such as calculation and judgment. Motor slowing and movement disorders are not prominent early features, differentiating it from subcortical dementias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DLB: Dementia with Lewy Bodies is a subcortical dementia showing fluctuations in cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonian features due to involvement of subcortical structures.

 

Option B. Huntington’s disease: It causes subcortical dementia due to degeneration of basal ganglia and associated white matter tracts, resulting in slowed thinking and psychomotor retardation.

 

Option D. Wilson’s disease: This is a metabolic disorder with basal ganglia involvement, leading to subcortical cognitive deficits along with movement abnormalities.

questions.text: A construction worker has unilateral facial anhidrosis after a back injury. Examination finding is shown below. Which location is the most likely site of lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. C) White ramus of T1

questions.text: A patient is lying in the hospital without any reaction or response. This behavior can be best described as:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negativism

 

Negativism refers to a resistance to instructions or attempts to be moved, without any apparent motive. The patient may remain unresponsive or may do the opposite of what is asked, reflecting a lack of cooperation not due to consciousness impairment but to psychomotor resistance. It is commonly seen in catatonic schizophrenia and other catatonic states.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannerism: It refers to goal-directed movements that are performed in an odd, exaggerated, or stylized manner, often seen in schizophrenia.

 

Option B. Stereotypy: It involves repetitive, non-goal-directed movements such as rocking or hand flapping, usually purposeless and uniform in pattern.

 

Option D. Echopraxia: It is the involuntary imitation of another person’s movements or gestures, also observed in catatonic and other psychotic disorders.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his parents due to behavioral difficulties. His mother says, "He is physically healthy and affectionate but has become more defiant and often resists our instructions about getting ready for bed. He plays roughly with his 6-year-old brother and sometimes throws tantrums when he has to share his toys or put them away." His preschool teacher describes him as an "active child" who sometimes talks out loud to classmates while the teacher is speaking. He is easily distracted and often gets up to walk around the classroom. The patient is able to draw circles, speak 3-word sentences, walk up the stairs with alternating feet, and use the toilet, but he cannot wipe himself. His parents express concern about his inability to fully dress himself and about his bed-wetting, which occurs approximately twice a week. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the child's behavior?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Normal development

 

At 3 years of age, mild oppositional behavior, distractibility, tantrums, and defiance toward parental instructions are normal parts of development as the child tests boundaries and autonomy. Bed-wetting (enuresis) is also common and not abnormal until after age 5. The ability to draw circles, use 3-word sentences, and walk up stairs with alternating feet are appropriate developmental milestones for a 3-year-old, indicating normal development rather than a behavioral disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder: ADHD requires symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity that are excessive for the developmental level and cause functional impairment in more than one setting, which is not evident here.

 

Option B. Conduct disorder: This involves persistent patterns of violating rules or the rights of others such as aggression, stealing, or deliberate destruction, not seen in this child’s case.

 

Option C. Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder: It is characterized by severe, recurrent temper outbursts and persistently irritable mood between outbursts, typically beginning before age 10, unlike the brief and situation-specific tantrums seen here.

questions.text: A patient presents with a geographic ulcer of the eye. What historical finding is most likely?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Use of topical steroids

questions.text: A newly married couple has come for counseling as the male partner has had difficulty maintaining an erection until the completion of sexual activity for the past 8 months. Which phase of the normal sexual cycle does this disorder belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arousal phase

 

Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of the arousal phase of the sexual response cycle. The arousal phase involves increased blood flow to the genitalia leading to erection in males and vaginal lubrication in females. Failure to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for sexual intercourse indicates a disturbance in this phase. The condition may have psychological, physiological, or mixed causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desire phase: This phase involves sexual interest and fantasies. Disorders here include hypoactive sexual desire disorder or sexual aversion disorder.

 

Option B. Orgasmic phase: This phase involves rhythmic muscular contractions and sexual release. Problems in this phase include premature ejaculation or orgasmic disorder.

 

Option D. Resolution phase: This is the post-orgasm relaxation and return to baseline; there are generally no major disorders associated with this phase.

 

‘Phases of Sexual Response’:

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Paralytic squint

questions.text: Which of the following selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors can be used in ADHD?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Atomoxetine

questions.text: Which surgery is most appropriate for a patient with congenital ptosis and poor levator action?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Frontalis suspension with fascia lata

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman has consistent intraocular pressures of 18-20 mmHg but shows paracentral scotoma on visual field test and a cup-disc ratio of 0.6. Gonioscopy reveals open angles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Normal tension glaucoma

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the OPD with complaints of premature ejaculation during intercourse. What is the non-pharmacological technique you will advise to the patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Squeeze technique

questions.text: 65-year-old woman with senile cataract shows the following findings. What is the stage of the cataract?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Morgagnian cataract
